entry.title: ANTIBOTS - PART IV - Taking a look at the decoded Incapsula Script

link.title: ANTIBOTS - PART IV - Taking a look at the decoded Incapsula Script

entry.content:
Weâ€™ve got over the first part! After beautifying the file, it looks something like this:
Kind of really ugly, ugly variable names, ugly String literals and scrolling down a little bit we can also see ugly Numeric literals!


Aight, once again, letâ€™s go for ASTExplorer

Hmm, so this whole script is made of a few variable declarations and also expression statements (P.S. they are IIFEâ€™s just like weâ€™ve met before)
Weâ€™d want, if possible, to do something about those ugly StringLiterals. We can see they have something in common, they are full of the prefix â€œ\xâ€ so letâ€™s try searching the web and see if thereâ€™s anything we can find about this.
Haha, bingo! The first google link is a stackoverflow link

The first (and only) answer speaks about Hex String Literals, interesting.. The answer talks only about escaped hex characters and how to transform them, what can we do in our case? Letâ€™s try doing this in the browserâ€™s sandbox (at the moment, you can do the same using NodeJS as a sandbox, itâ€™s not much different, Iâ€™ll tell you when the work gets messy)

Taking the first string from the array, we can see that after declaring it and when we try to print it, the value that gets printed is the escaped one already, great news!!! So this means that the hex strings get saved as ascii ones after declaration!
Letâ€™s jump into ASTExplorer and check the StringLiteral node:

After expanding parent nodes, we get to where we want to, our StringLiteral! It has a few properties, letâ€™s take a deeper look. We got its actual value, and rawValue and raw (raw refers to the raw raw, I assume, not even I am entirely sure, the raw raw value unescaped?!?!?)
Hereâ€™s the part where we get our hands dirty and actually start writing some deobfuscation in javascript! Letâ€™s go!
First, make sure you have the babel suite weâ€™ll use installed:
P.S. You can skip this, get the package-lock.json or package.json file from the Projectâ€™s Github Repo
After that, we are ready to start! Iâ€™ve already created a template file where you can get started without dealing with the input and output functions, you can find it on the Projectâ€™s Github Repo
template.js
In this tutorial we wonâ€™t care much about of this file, the only thing we need to care about at the moment is the part of code between the â€œ// YOUR VISITORS HEREâ€ comments, thatâ€™s where weâ€™ll write all our visitors and traverse the AST with them. The final script will be in the â€œincapsula_final.jsâ€ file
Letâ€™s jump right in and create our first visitor! It will seek out all hex StringLiterals and NumericLiterals and transform them to ascii values!
Now, let me explain: First, we create an object which will be our visitor (in our case â€œhexToAsciiVisitorâ€). Then, we proceed to only care about nodes of types StringLiteral and NumericLiterals that our visitor visits (All types that we wish to seek for must be made as methods for our visitor). Lastly, we make sure we pass them a â€œpathâ€ argument, path is kind of the main parent where our node resides, in the upcoming tutorials Iâ€™ll explain more in detail the path object which babel defines, itâ€™s a little more complex than othersâ€™ traversers (shift-ast for example), but it is really powerful!
Letâ€™s look at my process of thought when building this visitor

This is what a Literal looks specifically as a node made by babel. It seems as the problem we have here is the â€œrawâ€ property of the â€œextraâ€ property of our main node we arrived at! So by just deleting it, when the generator creates the final script from the AST, it no longer finds the â€œrawâ€ property so now relies on the â€œrawValueâ€ property which is what we want! Success!
Letâ€™s take a look at the output!
Much better!
Now, you have to keep in mind, sometimes, these Literals, more specifically, StringLiterals, contain Unicode characters. Unicode characters are represented something like this â€˜\u0123â€™ - with the â€˜\uâ€™ prefix and then 4 digits, some of these are not printable, so saving it to a file especially under something like Windows might cause unexpected issues or our end result of the script to change, so keep in mind to find a better solution in the future! Lucky for us, even though Incapsula contains unicode characters in the StringLiterals, they are printable!
For the final part of this article, thereâ€™s still of an annoying problem. Maybe the computer doesnâ€™t think this is a problem, but I donâ€™t think weâ€™re that ok as humans with those ugly variable names. Hereâ€™s where the renaming method comes into play! We can go through the script and rename each variable with a new name given by us!
Going back to the Projectâ€™s Github Repo, thereâ€™s a folder called â€œnamesâ€ and also a js file named â€œnames.jsâ€ that I created (and that has around 500 variable names, a few more than Incapsula, so we make sure we have plenty to replace with) and that will help you with the renaming! All you need to do is import it in your main script like this:
After that, letâ€™s get on to writing our visitor! Remember about our last visitor and how weâ€™ve accessed each node? We had to use â€œpath.nodeâ€ because the path also contains another property called â€œscopeâ€ that this one in turn contains all the references to that variable! Besides, the â€œscopeâ€ property has a method called â€œrenameâ€ which we can use to rename each variable name individually! Letâ€™s get back a little to the ASTExplorer and check for our variable/argument names.

What we can see is that each variable name, argument name, anything that points to a place where data is stored, the AST defines that as an â€œIdentifierâ€, so letâ€™s use that as the type of node we want to search for!
After we get to a node that is of â€œIdentifierâ€ type, we check to see if it starts with â€˜_0xâ€™, which is what the obfuscated Identifiers have as prefix. Then, if the Identifier we are at is, indeed, obfuscated, we rename it.
Run the script, and voila! This looks much better now, at least, easier for us to understand!
entry.summary: Weâ€™ve got over the first part! After beautifying the file, it looks something like this:

entry.title: ANTIBOTS - PART III - Taking a look at the first part of the Incapsula antibot

link.title: ANTIBOTS - PART III - Taking a look at the first part of the Incapsula antibot

entry.content:
Foreword:

  • Make sure you have NodeJS installed, a text editor or IDE (in my case I use VSCode) and most preferably Chrome as a browser (or any other Chromium based browser), but Firefox would suffice as well

  • From now on, the whole project will be hosted at antibot-incapsula

  • Tools used:

    • ASTExplorer

    • Google

  • Incapsula is obfuscated using Obfuscator.io, while learning I havenâ€™t used this and tried to do it all by myself which in my opinion was fun and made me use my brain more, though I strongly encourage its use in case you get stuck and need help or just want to see more obfuscations that it can do -> Obfuscator.io on Github

Iâ€™ve dug a little bit the web and found a website that uses Incapsula (will put the script I got up on github, since it changes values every time and they have checks in their backend, the script I provide will suffice for our case)

The script looks something like this:

Letâ€™s plug this big blob in ASTExplorer and see what kind of nodes is the our Program composed of!

Plugging the script in ASTExplorer tells us thereâ€™s a single node! So, if youâ€™ve spent a bit of time in the coding world youâ€™ll realize that this node is an IIFE (Immediately Invoked Function Expression), it is a function that has no name (just like a lambda) and gets executed the moment the interpreter gets to it.

Getting back to the script, and looking at the instructions following the definition of the boring long script, we see thereâ€™s an eval that evaluates the string that gets put into the â€˜zâ€™ variable

So the function thatâ€™s passed as an argument to the eval is kind of like a decoding function, transforms the b string into actual code that gets put into the z variable, which then gets executed (the eval function only executes the return/or the last value of the argument it gets passed)

What we can do is, instead of returning z, we can modify that line to log the script to the console, so it ends up being like this:

Since there are no checks inside the first script, you can just execute the script and pipe the output into a file like this:
entry.summary: Foreword: Make sure you have NodeJS installed, a text editor or IDE (in my case I use VSCode) and most preferably Chrome as a browser (or any other Chromium based browser), but Firefox would suffice as well From now on, the whole project will be hosted at antibot-incapsula Tools used: ASTExplorer Google Incapsula is obfuscated using Obfuscator.io, while learning I havenâ€™t used this and tried to do it all by myself which in my opinion was fun and made me use my brain more, though I strongly encourage its use in case you get stuck and need help or just want to see more obfuscations that it can do -> Obfuscator.io on Github

entry.title: ANTIBOTS - PART II - What is AST Manipulation, What is Regex, Why Would I Prefer One Over The Other?

link.title: ANTIBOTS - PART II - What is AST Manipulation, What is Regex, Why Would I Prefer One Over The Other?

entry.content:
We got to the point Iâ€™ve been waiting for: AST Manipulation and Regex.

First, what is regex? Regex is short for â€œregular expressionâ€ which basically specifies a pattern. Antibots are javascript, and javascript is just code. Code is made up of characters, so the whole script you could say is a loooooooooong string. Regex works on just thatâ€¦ Strings! You can match anything youâ€™d likeâ€¦ aaaaaaand anything you donâ€™t like, hereâ€™s an example what Iâ€™m talking about:

Hereâ€™s, in code, what a function in javascript looks like. Letâ€™s say our function solution was always just like that in code and we could find the code. We could create a regular expression (or actually 2) to find the key, great news!

Letâ€™s see what these would look like:

Making use of https://regex101.com we found a Regex that would suffice what we search for (at least the first part):

Our first matching group would be this one:

Now we can do the same for this string as well and get our secret key, you see where this is going..

Letâ€™s see how someone that creates these antibots would trick our code pretty easily!

Just like that, our first regex would have 2 matches this time, and the way we built it was to get the first match, so weâ€™d end up with the fake key instead of the real one!

Yes, sure someone could come up and say how we could edit our regex and make it even more complex to find the right key by detecting if it is a comment. Thatâ€™s not the point.

The point is, regexes become really long and hard, and hard to maintain, and scale, and ugly. Itâ€™s just not the right approach for if the antibot changes much. (even tho itâ€™s pretty fast I gotta admit, much faster than what Iâ€™m about to show you)

Thatâ€™s where AST comes into play!

AST is the short form of Abstract Syntax Tree. Javascript is basically a programming language, it has to be interpreted by the interpreter (The V8 engine also compiles the javascript to machine code, but again, Iâ€™m deviating too much)

When it gets interpreted, the interpreter also has a parser that transforms all that javascript into an AST, so what we are going to do is â€œtokenizeâ€ our script and transform it from there.

To understand tokenization better letâ€™s take a look at english. When we speak we combine WORDS together into SENTENCES. Words can be of different types NOUN, ADJECTIVE, ADVERB. So we can tokenize each word and specify what type it is. Thereâ€™s more to english, you can break down sentences into clauses and have a main and a secondary clause, itâ€™s a whole process!

Javascript is just the same, letâ€™s take for example a variable declaration (Iâ€™ll be using https://astexplorer.net for seeing the nodes inside the AST, I shall recommend you use it, too, since itâ€™s quite a powerful tool! Iâ€™ll also be using the BABEL suite for parsing the script into AST, traversing the AST and generating the final script back from AST):

Everything starts with the File object. Inside this object we got the Body array, which is an array that is composed of all the nodes inside the script. At the moment we only have 1 node and thatâ€™s the variable declaration in the left side!

Opening up the body array and expanding the first node we can see it is of type â€œVariableDeclarationâ€ and contains an array of declarations composed of only 1 declaration, a variable declaration! Letâ€™s open that up and see what weâ€™ll learn about itâ€¦

As we can see, the VariableDeclarator node is composed of 2 other nodes: its id (the variableâ€™s name) and the value it holds.

We can also see that the variable name is a node of type Identifier while the value it holds is a string literal (Peep that itâ€™s inside quotes)

A list of all the types can be found at: https://babeljs.io/docs/en/babel-types which will help us when doing transformations because weâ€™ll have to create nodes to replace other nodes!

So the basics of it is that, that is what AST is all about, tokenization, based on that, weâ€™ll be able to traverse the AST, find specific nodes by their types and also filter them by the type of nodes they contain and what not, endless possibilities! And youâ€™ll see it will actually be much easier to comprehend than regex, though this will come at the cost of time (parsing and traversing is pretty costly).
entry.summary: We got to the point Iâ€™ve been waiting for: AST Manipulation and Regex.

entry.title: ANTIBOTS - PART I - A short introduction to the Sneaker Development Industry and Antibots

link.title: ANTIBOTS - PART I - A short introduction to the Sneaker Development Industry and Antibots

entry.content:
Letâ€™s imagine for a second you want to bot a website. Though, why would you wanna do this? Well, nowadays, there are quite a few products that are produced in low quantity and the demand is pretty high. For example, GPUs or even sneakers.

You spend a few weeks/months researching and you tell yourself youâ€™re gonna start a bot of your own, as a personal bot or even to give it out to people as well. All goes well, you learn http, about requests, learn how to use Chrome Dev Tools and everything looks perfect! Thereâ€™s a catch though, these websites, well, they are sought by a lot of people, itâ€™s about who gets there first and checkouts, so you gotta be quick.

At first, you thought a browser bot would be enough, because you would have to just mimic the userâ€™s actions.. Thereâ€™s when antibots come in, they detect those browsers.. So you dig a little on the internet and you find that there are packages that make your browser undetected, success!!!

The development goes all well, and then you find yourself still not being able to checkout, cause thereâ€™s not only you that thought to bot this way, so what would be faster?

Going request mode, of course! But when you go request mode, thereâ€™s no way of actually going about the antibot.

These antibots are especially made to be run in a browser.

First, we have to understand what these antibots are and, at a basic level, how they work.

Thereâ€™s quite a few different ways antibots can detect that you are indeed sending illegitimate requests to the webserver, from what Iâ€™ve seen a few of the methods are:

Detecting and blocking the IP you are sending requests from - when you want to bot a website, you usually want to get as much quantity of a product as you can (there are people who have the funds for even 100 GPUâ€™s). This comes with a bit of headache at first, wouldnâ€™t you get blocked by the website if you sent 100 requests from your PC at the same time? But, bingo! Thereâ€™s a solution, proxies! You can first reroute your traffic through another machine so that the website thinks you are sending your requests from another location! These antibots that Iâ€™m talking about (for the moment DataDome) gather data of datacenters and botnets that exist and block their ipâ€™s, these seem to be the ones we canâ€™t really tackle with AST manipulation as the decisive factor if the user cooks or not itâ€™s the user himself or the botnet/datacenter proxies the user uses!

Making use of what the browser has to offer to either gather data and send it to an endpoint for a valid cookie, or just generating the cookie on the client itself! What the browser has to offer is related to its ability to manipulate the DOM and to use the specific browser variables (window, document, navigator)

We are going to focus the most on the 2nd type of antibots.

Letâ€™s expand a little more. How do these antibots work exactly? Well, they execute a series of instructions checking to be sure there exist the usual browser variables and even use the browser methods to manipulate the DOM to make sure that the antibot is not being sandboxed.

What do I mean by sandboxing? Well (now I have to deviate again, but itâ€™s for a good cause, trust me), letâ€™s look at chrome. These antibots are written in javascript, which basically powers web and clientside (along with WebAssembly but kinda no antibot uses WA at the moment, only the antibot for https://supremenewyork.com called Ticket tried to make use of it in 2020 and it was a disaster needless to say, but thatâ€™s for another time). Chrome uses the V8 engine to execute javascript (more about it here: https://v8.dev). Sandboxing, means to try and execute the script, but not in the browser specifically. The browser has to render elements on the screen, has to load plugins, it has to do a lot of things that eat up resources. Up until a decade ago (2009) javascript was only running in the browser, until someone came up with an idea to make use of the V8 engine to make it run javascript outside the browser! And thatâ€™s when NodeJS was created. NodeJS uses only the V8 engine and doesnâ€™t have the browser variables (window, document, navigator) but instead has some other variables and it can be detected pretty easy, so thatâ€™s why we have to be careful.

So what chance do we have at this?

By now, youâ€™d think our chances are pretty slim, but not really! Thereâ€™s ways, one of them would be to make Browser Bots even more hidden by playing with the variables they modify and trying to simulate user actions better.

Though, what weâ€™ll focus on is trying to deobfuscate these antibots, see how they work and make working gens for them.

What do I mean by deobfuscation? Well, software is still property, intellectual property. In the beginning of the information era obfuscation was used to make sure competitors and other people couldnâ€™t just steal the software they buy, repack it and resell it (there are also laws, but obfuscation is also to make it harder to even replicate, because it does some transformations that donâ€™t affect the computer since the computer executes the same instructions that lead to the same result, but itâ€™s certainly harder for a human being to understand the underlying way the program executes).

In our era, obfuscation is heavily used for antibots, so users canâ€™t just look at the antibots code, see what it checks for directly and create a solution that would bypass it.
entry.summary: Letâ€™s imagine for a second you want to bot a website. Though, why would you wanna do this? Well, nowadays, there are quite a few products that are produced in low quantity and the demand is pretty high. For example, GPUs or even sneakers.
